entry.title: Unlocking Insights from Data Point Comments in SAP Analytics Cloud in QRC3.2025
entry.content:
Unlocking Insights from Data Point Comments in SAP Analytics Cloud in QRC3.2025

In today's fast-paced business environment, the ability to quickly and accurately interpret data is crucial. One often overlooked but highly valuable source of insight is data point comments - unstructured text input that capture context, rationale, and qualitative feedback. 

SAP Analytics Cloud provides standard users with the advanced AI-Assisted capability to improve the understanding of data point comments effectively and efficiently. This premium AI-Assisted capability enables users to

  • Summarize long-form comment to surface key insights at a glance
  • Aggregate the comments from descendant cells for a consolidated view
  • Summarize the discussions throughout the whole thread to capture key points
  • Support authoring of comments to save time and improve clarity

To learn more about this feature and value proposition, please see the AI Feature Catalog in the SAP Discovery Center and the feature help. 

Prerequisites:  Check that you have met all the necessary prerequisites, which includes activating the feature, which is detailed here.

 

Basics of AI-Assisted Commenting

To use AI-Assisted Commenting functionalities, users need to have the necessary prerequisites to view or update data point comment and the ‘Execute’ permission for the Generative AI object type.

This powerful capability offers several key functionalities:

Shortening and Simplifying Long Form Commentary: Lengthy comments can be overwhelming and time-consuming to read. This feature shortens and simplifies these comments into the language set in your user profile, making them more digestible and easier to understand. This feature can be triggered when a comment exceeds 500 characters.

Aggregating Comments from Descendant Cells: Data often comes with comments scattered across various descendant cells. This feature aggregates these comments in the language configured in your user profile, providing a consolidated view that saves time and reduces the risk of missing important information.

Summarizing discussions from the whole thread:  Comment threads often consist of comments from multiple users and evolve into discussions. This feature generates a summary of the entire thread, highlighting the key points.

Supporting User Authoring of Comments: When users are authoring their comments, AI can assist in refining the comment into a more professional and polished version.

Consistent experience across different commenting interfaces: The experience in the table widget and comment widget are consistent. 

  • Note: aggregating comment from descendent cells is only available in table widget as the table widgets show the hierarchical view.

Reusing Comment Summaries within a session: Comment summaries are shared within the same session, eliminating the need for repeated regeneration.

 

Explore With Examples

Assuming you are an English speaker, and your user profile language is set to English. 

Aggregating Comments from Descendant Cells

When comment columns are enabled in the table, you can aggregate comment from descendent cells - even if they were authored in various local languages by their respective owners. With just one click, AI-Assisted Commenting generates a summary of descendent cells’ comments into your language.

 

Shortening and Simplifying Long Form Commentary

Now, let's take a closer look at Low Calorie Beer. The comment here is quite detailed and lengthy - and written in Chinese, a language you may not understand.

With the help of the system, a summary is automatically generated and translates into your preferred language. This allows you to quickly grasp the key points and understand the content effortlessly

 

Aggregating comments from the whole thread

Now we move on to Amber. The comment thread here contains inputs added at different points in time, reflecting an on-going discussion. With a single click, you can summarize the entire thread to get a comprehensive overview of all the key points.

 

Supporting User Authoring of Comments

You enter your comment, and the system helps rephrase your text into a more professional and polished version, helping you communicate more clearly and effectively. You can then further edit the rephrased comment text or save it directly to the comment thread. 

Consistency between table widget and commenting widget

The same functionalities are also available in comment widget, ensuring a consistent experience across different commenting interfaces.

 

Reusing Comment Summaries within a session

Comment summaries are shared within the same session, eliminating the need for repeated regeneration.

For example, if a summary or aggregation has already been generated for the comments on Low Calories Beer and Red Wine, subsequent summary requests within the current session can directly show the summary without triggering additional AI service calls.

Note: once the user logs out or if other users initiate the requests, the summary or aggregation need to be regenerated again.

 

Conclusion

Overall, the AI-Assisted Commenting feature is a powerful addition to SAP Analytics Cloud, enhancing the way users interact with and understand their data. By simplifying comments, aggregating information, breaking down language barriers, and supporting user input, this tool significantly improves data comprehension and decision-making.

entry.title: はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - 共有方法
entry.content:
本ブログシリーズはSAP Analytics CloudのBI機能を使ってダッシュボードやレポートの作成を行う方を対象とし、SAP Analytics CloudのBIにおける基本の操作やTipsをハンズオン形式でご紹介します。

本ブログでは、モデルやストーリー、フォルダの共有方法についてご紹介いたします。

 

目次：

  • SAP Analytics Cloudにおける共有の概要
  • 共有方法[ハンズオン]
    • 公開フォルダへの格納
    • ファイルの共有
    • カタログへの公開

※ベースとなるサンプルストーリーの作成⼿順は、はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityでご紹介しています。
※ SAP Analytics Cloudは、四半期に１度のペースで製品のバージョンアップが実施されます。そのため今後のバージョンアップにより、本ブログで紹介する画⾯キャプチャや、操作が異なる可能性があることをご了承ください。（本ブログは2025年8⽉に作成しています。）

 

 

SAP Analytics Cloudにおける共有の概要

SAP Analytics Cloudでは、作成したストーリーやフォルダを共有することができます。ユースケースや共有範囲に応じて、以下の3つを使い分けて共有を行います。

①  公開フォルダへの格納
チームや組織単位で継続的に利用・更新されるコンテンツを一元管理する方法です。
公開フォルダは、テナントにアクセスできるすべてのユーザーが閲覧することができるため、社内で同一コンテンツを管理・更新する場合に適しており、フォルダ構造を整理することで運用効率も向上します。

②  共有フォルダの作成・ファイルの共有
特定のユーザーやチームに対して、個別のファイルやフォルダを直接共有する方法です。
アクセス権限を対象ごとに細かく設定できるため、一時的なレビューや限定的なコラボレーションに適しています。共有範囲を最小限に抑えたい場合や、プロジェクトごとに関係者が異なる場合に有効です。
フォルダやファイルごとにアクセス権限（閲覧、編集、フルコントロールなど）を設定することができます。

③  カタログへの公開
組織全体で広く利用してほしいコンテンツを、ポータル形式で発見・利用できるようにする方法です。
標準レポート、承認済みテンプレート、ガバナンスされたモデルなどをカタログに公開することで、誰でも容易に検索・参照できるようになります。社内全体でのストーリーの活用促進やナレッジ共有に有効で、コンテンツの発信手段として活用されます。
カタログはチーム単位での共有になります。

詳しくはHelp Portalもご参照ください：
ファイルまたはフォルダの共有
カタログへのコンテンツの公開および共有

 

 

共有方法[ハンズオン]

1. 公開フォルダへ格納しよう！

今回は「SAC BI blog」フォルダ内にある「S_SampleStory_Share」のストーリーを公開フォルダに格納します。

1.1.  左のサイドメニューから「ファイル」を選択し、格納したいファイルを選択します。

 

1.2.  「S_SampleStory_Share」を選択し、「フォルダアクション」から、「移動先...」を選択します。
※ストーリーを共有する際は、それに紐づくモデルも同時に共有するようにしてください。

 

1.3. 「公開」フォルダを選択し、「移動」をクリックします。
※「」マークがあるフォルダが共有フォルダになります。

 

 

 2. 作成したストーリーを共有しよう！

次に、特定のユーザー向けに作成したストーリーを公開します。今回は「SAC BI blog」フォルダ内にある「S_SampleStory_Share」のストーリーを格納します。

2.1. 左のサイドメニューから「ファイル」を選択し、格納したいファイルを選択します。「」マークをクリックし、「共有...」を選択します。
※ストーリーを共有する際は、それに紐づくモデルも同時に共有するようにしてください。

 

2.2 .  「ユーザーまたはチームの追加」から、共有したいユーザーもしくはチームを追加し、アクセス範囲を選択します。
「ユーザー定義...」を選択すると、細かいアクセス範囲の設定を行うことができます。

2.3. アクセス範囲が決まったら、「共有」を押します。「新しい受信者に電子メールを送信」にチェックを入れると、メールで通知することも可能です。
※同様にモデルやフォルダも共有することが可能です。

 

 

3. カタログに公開しよう！

次に、作成したストーリーをカタログに公開します。今回は「SAC BI blog」フォルダ内にある「S_SampleStory_Share」のストーリーを公開します。

3.1.  左のサイドメニューから「ファイル」を選択し、格納したいファイルを選択します。「」マークをクリックし、「カタログに公開...」を選択します。


3.2.  「チームの追加...」から、公開したいチームを追加します。「読み込みアクセス権を付与」を選択すると、選択されたチームのメンバーが公開されたフォルダを開くことができます。

3.3. （任意）ユーザーが見えるカタログの外見を編集することができます。
「詳細の編集...」を選択し、ストーリーのタイトルや説明、画像などを追加することができます。

カタログの外見はカードプレビューより確認することができます。

 

3.4.  「公開」をクリックすることでカタログを公開することができます。

 

今回はSACの共有方法のご紹介でした。SAP Analytics Cloudは他にも様々な表現や便利な機能があり、本ブログシリーズでご紹介しています。はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - シリーズまとめ - SAP Communityからご参照ください。

entry.title: Re: SAP Mobile Start via SAP Start Booster – No Apps or P...
entry.content:
Hello @Vijjusk 

Here’s an overview of the issue and clear steps to resolve it.

  • The apps you see on mobile come from your SAP Start content site roles (good).
  • The “Products” area on the SAP Start home/site directory is not auto-filled by roles. It stays empty until an administrator configures product links S/4HANA, Ariba, Concur) in Site Settings → Products.

The reason you can’t do it is because you lack SAP Start admin rights at that site.

What to ask your BTP admin for

Assign these role collections to your user within the BTP subaccount that hosts SAP Start / Work Zone. Names may differ slightly depending on the tenant.t

  • SAP Start Administrator (required to access Site Settings → Products)
  • If you’re on Work Zone/Launchpad service: Launchpad_Admin (or Workzone_Admin)

Then proceed with this.

  1. Open Site Manager → Site Settings → Products.
  2. Add Product entries (name, icon, target URL to each product’s home).
  3. Save, log out/in. The Products section will now list them.

Your setup is correct for app tiles; the empty Products panel is normal until an admin adds a product links.

Let me  know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud?
entry.content:
**Updated August 2025**

Welcome to our blog series focused on the SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

This guide provides a comprehensive, step-by-step approach to help you estimate the capacity units (CU) needed for your business case (before purchasing) or how you can distribute them across your solution components (after signing a contract) for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) within SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

This post belongs to a blog series with 4 parts: 

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Analytics Cloud (this post)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Datasphere (coming soon)
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator for SAP Databricks (coming soon)

In SAC within BDC, the Capacity Units (CU) vary by license type and quantity of licenses. 

Following SAP Best Practices, two system types are recommended, one for each: 1) Test/QA and 2) Production.

1) For Test/QA, there is 1 SAC license type:

  • SAC Test:
    • It includes all SAC Planning Professional features but in a non-productive environment
    • Minimum requirement: 20 users to provision a test tenant, which refers to a minimum of 941 CU/Month (or 47.05 CU per user)

2) For production, there are 3 SAC license types:

  • SAC Business Intelligence (or SAC BI): 
    • It includes data exploration, visualization, and predictive analytics for insights and informed decision making. No planning features are available
    • Minimum requirement: 25 users to create a prod tenant (scenario 1), which refers to 640 CU/Month (or 25.60 CU per user)
  • SAC Planning Standard (or SAC Planning Std):
    • It includes basic planning functionalities with integrated predictive capabilities like running simulations, data input and scenario modelling
    • Minimum requirement: ⚠️  We can't provision a prod tenant only with Planning Std licenses; we need at least 10 Planning Std users and 1 Planning Prof user 
  • SAC Planning Professional (or SAC Planning Prof): 
    • It includes everything in Standard plus advanced planning capabilities, including building planning models, complex data actions, allocation rules, and detailed analysis and forecasting.
    • Minimum requirement: 10 Planning Std users and 1 Planning Prof user (scenario 2), which refers to 1548.93 CU/Month (72.85 CU per user for Planning Std and 820.43 CU per user for Planning Prof)

Below, you can find a summary table for the available licenses according each tenant type. 

Business TypesMinimum of licensesMinimum of CU
Test/QA20 SAC Test941 CU/Month
Production (Scenario 1)25 SAC BI640 CU/Month
Production (Scenario 2)1 SAC Planning Prof and 10 SAC Planning Std 1548.93 CU/Month

📌  Want to estimate more than the minimum? No problem! Below, you can find a step-by-step:

1. Open SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator.

2. Select your "Hyperscaler" and "Data Center".

3. Click "Add" and double-click "SAP Analytics Cloud".

4. Enter the number of licenses for each SAC license type. In this example, we use 25 for SAC BI, 10 SAC Planning Std and 1 SAC Planning Prof. 

5. The final CU amount will appear in the top-right corner. 

Image 1

Image 2

👉  For details on provisioning SAC within BDC, please check out our dedicated blog post. 

💡  If you want to know more about the different SAC license types, read more here and here.

entry.title: Alerts not resolving dynamic recipient information
entry.content:
Description of the Issue:
We want configured service anniversary alerts using the standard Alerts & Notifications framework. The alerts are being generated, but the recipient information is not being dynamically resolved at runtime. Instead, the system appears to use static data, resulting in incorrect or missing recipients when organizational changes occur (e.g., manager changes, matrix relationship changes, cost center lead updates).

Steps to Reproduce:

  1. Configure an anniversary alert with a workflow that includes dynamic roles (e.g., Manager, Matrix Manager, Cost Center Lead).

  2. Run the Off-Cycle Event Batch Processing and EC Alerts and Notifications jobs.

  3. Change the manager or matrix relationship of the employee before the anniversary date.

  4. Observe that the alert still references the old manager, or no recipient is resolved.

Expected Behavior:
At the time of sending the alert, the system should dynamically resolve the recipients based on the current relationships (Manager, Matrix Manager, Cost Center Lead, etc.).

Actual Behavior:
The system does not refresh or pull the current dynamic relationships. Alerts either:

  • go to the outdated manager, or

  • fail to determine recipients and are not delivered.

Impact:

  • Notifications are not reaching the correct recipients.

  • HR and People Services cannot rely on alerts for anniversaries and need to maintain manual workarounds.

  • This affects employee engagement processes (recognition of service anniversaries).

Question / Request:

  • Is this the expected behavior of the Alert & Notification framework, or should dynamic recipient information (from workflows / dynamic roles) be re-evaluated at runtime?

  • If this is a defect, please advise on fix or workaround.

  • If this is a limitation, please suggest recommended best practice to achieve anniversary notifications with always up-to-date recipient information.

entry.title: IPアドレス変更時のRFC宛先設定変更について
entry.content:
Solmanサーバ、ERPサーバ、SAPRouterサーバについてIPアドレスが変更となり、
後述のRFC宛先についてIPアドレスが設定されているため、トランザクションコードSM59で変更しようとしております。
それぞれ括弧内に記載したユーザ（「Logonとセキュリティ」タブに登録されているユーザ）のパスワード欄に何を入力すればよいのか教えていただけませんでしょうか。
具体的な値や確認方法、もしくは作成し直す場合はその手順を教えていただきたく、よろしくお願い致します。

■SolmanサーバのRFC宛先
＜Solman関連と推測されるRFC宛先＞
SM_PRDCLNT900_LOGIN    （<ユーザ指定なし>）
SM_PRDCLNT900_READ    （SM_SSM）
SM_PRDCLNT900_TMW    （SMTMSSM）
SM_PRDCLNT900_TRUSTED    （<ユーザ指定なし>）


■ERPサーバのRFC宛先
＜Solman関連と推測されるRFC宛先＞
SM_SSMCLNT100_BACK    （SMB_PRD）
SM_SSM_TRUSTED_BACK    （<ユーザ指定なし>）


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: IPアドレス変更時のRFC宛先設定変更について
entry.content:
パスワードはお客様側で定義されるものなので、SM59で直接に新しいパスワードをご入力していただくか、
t-code:solman_setup→管理対象システム設定→PRDシステム→ステップ3.Maintain RFCsの編集モードで、Advanced Modeをご選択いただき、Options for RFC Creationに、
SAPRouter Stringのチェックバックスを選定し、SAPRouter StringのIPアドレスをご入力いただき、該当RFCを選択してUpdate Passwordのオプションでパスワードの変更ができます。

entry.title: はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - リンク付き分析
entry.content:
本ブログシリーズはSAP Analytics CloudのBI機能を使ってダッシュボードやレポートの作成を行う方を対象とし、SAP Analytics CloudのBIにおける基本の操作やTipsをハンズオン形式でご紹介します。

本ブログでは、ウィジェット間でフィルタや選択を同期させて、横断的に分析したい際にご使用いただけるリンク付き分析の作成についてご紹介いたします。

 

 

目次：

  • SAP Analytics Cloudにおけるリンク付き分析の概要
  • リンク付き分析の作成方法[ハンズオン]

※ベースとなるサンプルストーリーの作成⼿順は、はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityでご紹介しています。
※ SAP Analytics Cloudは、四半期に１度のペースで製品のバージョンアップが実施されます。そのため今後のバージョンアップにより、本ブログで紹介する画⾯キャプチャや、操作が異なる可能性があることをご了承ください。（本ブログは2025年8⽉に作成しています。）

 

 

SAP Analytics Cloudにおけるリンク付き分析の概要

リンク付き分析は、ストーリー内のあるウィジェット（チャート／テーブル／地図など）で行ったデータポイントの選択や階層ドリルの操作を、他のウィジェットにそのまま適応させる仕組みです。

ページ内の視点が揃い、関連するグラフやテーブルが同じ条件で一斉に切り替わるため、指標同士の関係を迷わず追えます。四半期ごとのKPIを横並びで比較したいとき、異常に見えるピークの原因を深掘りしたいときなどに便利です。

どのウィジェットを連動対象にするかは個別に指定でき、ストーリー/ページ内のすべてのウィジェットに適用したり、特定のウィジェットのみに適用するように設定もできます。

詳しくは SAP Help Portal も参照ください：リンク付き分析の設定 | SAP Help Portal

 

 

リンク付き分析の作成方法

0. はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - サンプルモデル／ストーリーの作成 - SAP Communityで作成したストーリーを編集モードで開こう！

0.1 ナビゲーションバーのファイルより作成したストーリーを開き、「編集」をクリックします。

 

1. リンク付き分析を作成しよう！

1.1.  事業セグメントごとの売上高のチャートにリンク付き分析を適用します。「…」マークから、「その他のオプション」、「リンク付き分析」、「設定」を開きます。
※ビルダパネルからも同様の設定をすることができます。

 

1.2. フィルタの適用範囲を設定します。「ページ上のすべてのウィジェット」を選択し、「データポイントの選択に応じてフィルタリング」にチェックを入れます。

「データポイントの選択に応じてフィルタリング」をオンにすると、ウィジェット上で特定のディメンションをクリックした時に、その条件が他のウィジェットにも自動で反映されます。
一方、この設定をオフにした場合は、リンク付き分析を設定したウィジェットに対してフィルタを適用するまでは、他のウィジェットにはフィルタがかかりません。

 

1.3. リンク付き分析を作成することができました。

「データポイントの選択に応じてフィルタリング」をオンにしたため、チャート上で「ベストITS」をクリックした時に、その条件が他のチャートにも自動で反映されているのがわかります。

 

今回はリンク付き分析のご紹介でした。SAP Analytics Cloudは他にも様々な表現や便利な機能があり、本ブログシリーズでご紹介しています。はじめてのSAP Analytics Cloud BI - シリーズまとめ - SAP Communityからご参照ください。

entry.title: Re: SAP Account Query - how to change S-user email address
entry.content:
客户您好，

如果您想更改S-账号的注册邮箱，请您参考知识文档3108466 - How to update the email address for S-user IDs - SAP for Me并联系您公司的账号管理员，超级管理员或云管理员进行更改。

账号本人无法更改自己的注册邮箱。管理员本人也无法更改自己的邮箱。必须联系另一位管理员进行邮箱的更改。

如果您的S-账号绑定了UID, 那您的新邮箱也需要绑定UID，具体步骤请参考知识文档2882908。之后再联系您的管理员在User Management APP中为您更改邮箱。

希望以上信息能够对您有所帮助。

如有任何问题，请随时反馈，并顺祝商祺~

SAP Support

************************************************************************************************************

Dear customer,

To change S-user email address, could you pls kindly refer to KBA 3108466 - How to update the email address for S-user IDs - SAP for Me and contact your company's Super Administrators, User Administrators, or Cloud Administrators to change the email address for you?

S-users can no longer manage their own email addresses in SAP for Me, only the administrators can. Also, administrators cannot change their own email addresses either, so another administrator must do this for them.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Sunset of BEx Tools - Frequently Asked Questions and Answers (FAQ)
entry.content:
@bellec 

Am I affected by this alert if I export data from a report generated by a web template into microsoft excel?

No. You are using web template which is based on the BI Java and then exporting the results to Excel. So you are not impacted

if we have OFFICE 365, are we already affected by this alert ?

If you are using latest excel version with office 365, you may not be impacted. But BEx Analyzer will not be supported beyond October 2025 and SAP GUI patches delivered  after October 2025 may also not contain BEx Analyzer which may disrupt your reporting using BEx Analyzer after SAP GUI patch update.

I am planning to install support packages on my BW 7.5. Could this cause incompatibility issues in the BEX Analyzer or Broadcaster?

No. SAP BW 7.5 SP upgrade is not linked to the supportability of BEx Analyzer of Broadcaster. But if you upgrade to BW/4HANA, BEx Analyzer and Bradcaster will anyways not be supported and need to be replaced with Analysis for office.

entry.title: Re: Need SAP Mentor
entry.content:
Hi Laxmi,

First of all, thank you for sharing your thoughts regarding your current situation. I mentor people in SAP community and can easily say you're not alone. The fast-changing tech space makes you feel so. And there has been a shift as well, earlier we used to stick to one skill for years, with very minimal changes, but today, in the cloud world, we need to upskill ourselves continuously.

Coming to your profile, it would be good if I could understand what your strengths are in terms of current skill, and what your goals would be (let's be honest, we all want to see ourselves at a different stage, even if we work on same technology). But to start with, here is what I can recommend:

1. The smoothest transition for any BASIS resource would be knowing about SAP BTP and then diving deep into SAP BTP administration. Please go through these courses to start with:

  • Exploring SAP BTP
  • Administrating SAP BTP
  • Architecting security for SAP BTP

2. Once you have an idea about SAP BTP, I would recommend going through the Exploring the role of SAP System Admin course.  This course explains various tasks a system admin would perform in the new world 🙂

3. Once you have gone through all the courses, you now need to decide whether you want to be an admin in the app development/automation, integration, data & analytics or AI domain of SAP BTP. You can choose any domain of interest, and explore the rest later.

4. Explore SAP Cloud ALM as well.

5. You also need to understand various S/4 offerings and the responsibilities of a system admin in each case. There are learning journeys on learning.sap.com.

6. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out!

Happy learning!

Cheers,

Vik

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/krvikash/

entry.title: 在eclipse中使用ADT插件做RAP开发报表使用https调用odata接口遇到报错"Selection is empty. Processing is canceled!"
entry.content:
Dear SAP expert,

我们在eclipse中使用ADT插件做RAP开发报表时，数据没有合适的CDS，但是有对应的API：API_MRP_MATERIALS_SRV_01/SupplyDemandItems ，此API在使用postman测试时加上参数（?$filter=Material eq '******' and MRPPlant eq '****' and PeriodType eq '*'）就能得到想要的数据，在RAP代码中使用https调用odata接口会遇到报错：Selection is empty. Processing is canceled! ， 这是因为接口没有读取到我设置的参数，无论是使用set_form_field还是使用set_query都无法设置有效的参数，是否还有其他设置参数的方法，或者有https的其他类可以使用。

代码：

DATA: http_client TYPE REF TO if_web_http_client,

lo_response TYPE REF TO if_web_http_response,

lv_url type string,

lv_usename type string,

lv_pwd type string.

 

" 通过 URL 启用通信

DATA(lo_url_destination) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_url(

lv_url ).

 

" 获取 请求的 client

http_client = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_url_destination ).

 

DATA(req) = http_client->get_http_request( ).

 

"设置账号密码

req->set_authorization_basic( i_username = lv_usename i_password = lv_pwd ).

"设置参数

req->set_form_field( i_name = 'Material' i_value = '00698-321/0000' ).

req->set_form_field( i_name = 'MRPPlant' i_value = '8900' ).

req->set_form_field( i_name = 'PeriodType' i_value = '2' ).

req->set_header_field( i_name = 'Accept' i_value = 'application/json' ).

"执行查询方法

lo_response = http_client->execute( if_web_http_client=>get ).

"获取返回数据 （报错：Selection is empty. Processing is canceled!）

DATA(lv_random_value) = lo_response->get_text( ).

 

DATA lt_response TYPE ty_response.

 

/ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(

EXPORTING json = lv_random_value

CHANGING data = lt_response )

 

Best regards,

Joey

entry.title: Re: Manage payments for import purchases
entry.content:
Since the Import Shipment object is not available, you can simulate shipment-level grouping using:

  • Custom fields or tags on PO header level via Custom Fields and Logic app.
  • Group ID or Reference Number manually maintained across POs.
  • Use Supplier Invoice Grouping or Payment Proposal filters based on shared attributes (e.g., vendor, delivery date, Incoterms).

This won’t give you full shipment tracking, but it allows you to drive payments or advances based on a shared reference.

You can still mass update conditions using Mass Changes to Purchasing Info Records Fiori app F1758. Download the Excel template, go to the Pricing tab, and add or update condition types like FGW1 (freight), CFxx (customs). Assign the Pricing Partner (customs agent or freight forwarder). Adjust rates or validity dates as needed. Upload the file, preview changes, and activate. This is the recommended method for updating import-related conditions in bulk.

entry.title: 【云启创新】2025年下半年SAP S/4HANA Cloud Product Expert Training大中华区专场系列盛大启幕！

- 10场行业洞察与技术实践分享，内容涉及制造、财务、供应链、行业定制方案、AI应用等多个核心方向；
- 深度剖析SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508版本的新特性与应用场景，抢占企业数字化新机遇；
- 现场互动问答，与专家线上零距离交流，获取一线经验；

▶ 9月15日（上午）：GTM策略与市场布局 —— 中国市场发展新机遇（Alex Zheng）

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: Issue with Default "Tax Cal...
entry.content:
Go to the BP master data in the Fiori app: Maintain Business Partner. Navigate to the Customer (Fin. Accounting) role → Tax Data tab. If “Tax Calculation Brazil” appears, try to manually delete or overwrite it with “Tax Calculation South Korea.” If it’s non-editable, it may be inherited from a default configuration or external tax engine.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud often uses external tax engines (e.g., Vertex, Thomson Reuters) for localization like Brazil. Check if your system has any integration routes or templates still referencing Brazil. Use the SAP Integration Suite or Tax Service Trace Transaction to inspect payloads and routing logic. If Brazil is hardcoded or defaulted in any route, it could be injecting the tax schema into BP creation.

Even though Brazil isn’t scoped, some default localization content may still be present. In CBC, go to “Configuration Activities” and search for “Tax Determination” or “Localization”. Look for any Brazil-specific entries under Define Tax Classification > Assign Tax Procedure to Country > Define Tax Codes. If found, remove or deactivate them and re-deploy the configuration.

To rule out inheritance, Create a new BP manually, without copying from any existing template. Assign only South Korea-specific company code and roles. Check if “Tax Calculation Brazil” still appears. If not, the issue is likely tied to the original BP template or copy logic.

entry.title: Upload and Download Invoice Image on RAP Application
entry.content:
Introduction:

The ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) provides a streamlined, standardized way to build enterprise-grade Fiori apps on SAP BTP ABAP Environment — including support for file handling.


Unlike traditional approaches where developers manually code file upload/download logic, RAP leverages large object (LOB) semantics, MIME type control, and built‑in media stream handling to manage file content and metadata automatically.
In this project, we implement a draft‑enabled RAP application for invoice management that allows users to upload, preview, download, and delete attachments directly from the Fiori UI.

Using only CDS annotations and metadata definitions — without custom CRUD code — the RAP runtime takes care of:

  • Persisting file content in database LRAW/RAWSTRING fields,
  • Validating file MIME types (e.g., JPEG, PNG),
  • Exposing file streams for download via OData V4,
  • Linking attachments to business object instances in draft or active state.

By combining RAP’s managed draft capabilities and UI annotations like @Semantics.largeObject and @ui.headerInfo.imageUrl, we achieve a clean, zero‑custom‑code solution for common file management needs in business applications.

 

Objectives:

Enable file upload and download functionality for a Draft enabled RAP Application

 

Tasks

  1. Database Table: Create the Attachment, MIME and File name fields in Database table
  2. CDS Interface View:  the LargeObject semantics for the file like file types (in our case we set this to jpeg and PNG file types)
  3. Metadata View: Declare the imageURL in UI.headerinfo and hide filename and MIME type fields.
  4. Test the application for file upload and download for a record selected by user

 

Steps in Detail

  • Step 1 :Database Table will must have the following fields

     

attachment : /dmo/attachment;
mime_type  : /dmo/mime_type;
file name  : /dmo/filename;

 

  • Step 2 : CDS Interface view declaration:
@Semantics.largeObject: { mimeType: 'MimeType', //case-sensitive
                          fileName: 'FileName', //case-sensitive
               acceptableMimeTypes: ['image/png', 'image/jpeg'],
      contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT }

attachment as Attachment,
@Semantics.mimeType: true
mime_type as MimeType,
file name as FileName,

 

  • Step 3: Metadata View
  imageUrl:       'Attachment',           //case-sensitive in UI.HeaderInfo.
QUI.identification: [ { position: 110 } ]
Attachment;

@UI.hidden: true
MimeTypej

@UI.hidden: true
FileName;

@UI.hidden: true
LocalLastChangedAt;

 

  • Step 4: Test the Application: Open your RAP UI App. Click “Go” Button, to see records listed from Database table.

 

 

Navigate to a record by clicking on the list displayed, you will see the field for Attachments.

 

You can hit the upload button to upload the file: (in our case we have limited the file type to JPEG and PNG files). Once uploaded the file will be displayed as an icon. You can also see the updated file on the top left corner of the record when the upload is successful.  This means that the attachment has been successfully uploaded against the selected record in the database.

 

User is able to delete the file by selecting the delete icon next to the upload/download button when the record is in Creation or Edit mode.

 

 

When the record is in Display mode, if there is a image attached to the record, the file name is hyperlink enables so that the user is able to download file onto local drive.

 

Conclusion

This demonstrates that RAP’s built‑in file handling significantly reduces the complexity of implementing document management features in SAP applications.
By simply:

  • Declaring attachment, file name, and MIME type fields in the DB table,
  • Annotating them with large object semantics and acceptable MIME types,
  • Using metadata extensions to control UI display and hide technical fields,

the RAP framework automatically provides end‑to‑end file upload, delete, and download capabilities in the generated Fiori app — fully integrated with the business object lifecycle and draft handling. In our invoice scenario, users can intuitively manage image attachments within the object page: upload new files in edit mode, delete them when needed, and download them in display mode.

No manual OData stream provider or complex frontend logic was necessary — the RAP runtime, guided by CDS annotations, handled storage, retrieval, and MIME type enforcement for us.

This confirms RAP’s position as a “declarative-first” development model — enabling developers to focus on the data model and business logic, while the framework transparently implements recurring technical patterns like file management.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 5: SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
This fifth post in my series gives an overview of latest UX innovations in SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass, products for managing your spend (procurement) and external workforce. For SAP Ariba: Joule is now available for selected products, on-boarding guidance is provided by WalkMe, and we have some additional AI-assistance in SAP Ariba Category Management, amongst other enhancements. For SAP Fieldglass, Joule is now available too, and the SOW (Statement of Work) dashboard can now be adapted per user role, ensuring that users see what fits best for them. Also, you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

 

SAP Ariba

Here are the recent UX innovations that I have picked:

  • On-boarding guidance via WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform.
  • Joule, our AI copilot, available for selected SAP Ariba products.
  • UX enhancements in Category Management: Supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, plus some more minor enhancements in details.
  • Integration of the SAP User Research Panel into selected products’ built-in user feedback surveys.

On-boarding guidance via WalkMe

When new employees join the procurement team, we now make it easier for them to get up and running with SAP Ariba by providing enhanced step-by-step guidance on how to get typical tasks done in the system. With the 2508 release, we provide WalkMe for the following SAP Ariba products:

  • SAP Ariba Buying
  • SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing
  • SAP Ariba Contracts
  • SAP Ariba Invoice Management
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Risk

WalkMe offers engaging, intuitive, role-based guidance to help user quickly achieve value by minimizing barriers during initial use of the product and creating a great first experience. Figure 1 gives you an idea of what this looks like, showing first the list of activities available for the current user context within SAP Ariba Sourcing, and then an example of one of the guidance steps (the fourth step after the user had selected “Create a guided sourcing project”).

Figure 1: An example of WalkMe for SAP Ariba Sourcing. Alt Text: two cut-outs from screenshots are shown. On the left the WalkMe panel lists two options “Create a sourcing project” and “Create a guided sourcing event”. On the right, the UI for “Create guided sourcing project” is shown with a pop-over explaining the options for a selecting either a “Single event” or a “Full project”, and explaining why the system has pre-selected “Full project”.

In the guided sourcing capability for SAP Ariba Sourcing, Walkthroughs are available for the following tasks:

  • Create a guided sourcing project.
  • Create a guided souring event.
  • Create a guided sourcing event in a project.
  • Invite suppliers.

Check out the video below to see WalkMe in action in guided sourcing, and find out more in the documentation:

  • Video: Explore Guided Sourcing Events with WalkMe (3:35 min.)
  • Documentation: WalkMe Available in SAP Ariba Products.

You can go one step further and provide content tailored to your organization by purchasing WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba Solutions. For more information about WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba, visit the WalkMe home page.

Joule for SAP Ariba

With the 2508 release, Joule, our AI copilot, is now available for:

  • Supplier management.
  • Guided sourcing.
  • Guided buying.

Figure 2 shows an example of what it looks like when you open up Joule in guided buying, where it provides suggestions for what you could ask. These suggestions are clickable, but you can of course type in your text directly.

Figure 2: Joule for guided buying. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jitesh, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Approvers of a requisition”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

The currently availabe capabilities are listed in the documentation:

  • Joule Capabilities in Supplier Management.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Sourcing.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Buying.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it is planned to be made generally available to customers.

UX Enhancements in SAP Ariba Category Management

This section covers UX enhancements for supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, and provides a link to more UX enhancements in detail.

Supplier Preferencing

When buying from various suppliers, it’s good to know how these suppliers view their relationship with your company. Do they value your custom highly? Or at the opposite extreme, do they see you as a nuisance, i.e. low volume but high effort and hence unprofitable?

Supplier preferencing is an established approach that helps organizations understand how they are perceived by vendors. By leveraging this insight, businesses can strengthen supplier relationships, foster collaboration, and improve supply chain effectiveness.

Supplier preferencing involves evaluating how suppliers view a buying organization based on two key dimensions:

  • Attractiveness of Account: How appealing the buying organization is to the supplier, influenced by factors like reputation, growth potential, and ease of doing business.
  • Relative Value of Business: The monetary value or strategic importance the buying organization's spend brings to the supplier.

Each dimension can be assessed as “high” or “low”, resulting in four possible categories Core, Development, Nuisance and Exploitable, as explained in the

  • Documentation: Supplier Preferencing.

We now provide an intuitive user experience for buyers to apply supplier preferencing very easily, and get an easy to understand overview for each supplier and for each strategy and plan you have created for buying from that supplier. Figure 3 shows an example for a fictitious supplier called SpeedShip, where the outcome of assessments for various strategy and plans are shown.

Figure 3: Supplier preferencing example in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing with a heading “SpeedShip”, below that four tabs “Overview”, “Performance”, “SWOT” and “Supplier Preferencing” (selected). The pop-over summarizes the supplier as “Nuisance”, with a timestamp of last update, and shows a list of Assessments.

Figure 4 shows an extract of the questionnaire which employees can fill out in order to assess the supplier preference.

Figure 4: Supplier preferencing questionnaire in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing part of a Supplier Preferencing Assessment Questionnaire, with yes/no questions on the attractiveness of account, such as “Do you see our organization as a potential strategic partner in the industry?”.

Strategy and Plan: Collaborate Externally by Sharing Plans as PDF

Now, Category Managers can share their strategy and plan documents with stakeholders who do not have access to SAP Ariba Category Management, by exporting them to a PDF file.

Stakeholders can review the strategy and plan outside of SAP Ariba Category Management, provide input, follow its direction, and consider it when developing related strategies. The exported file contains the most relevant content from all tools organized into pages so it can also be used as slide deck. Figure 5 shows the export screen, with parts of the first two pages with text summary and details, and Figure 6 shows how charts and tables are nicely presented as a page within the PDF file.

Figure 5: Creating a PDF file for the category strategy and plan within SAP Ariba Category Management, for sharing with stakeholders. Alt Text: A screenshot of the application Category Strategy and Plan with a pop-over for exporting to PDF. The left two thirds of the pop-over shows a preview of the PDF, showing the Strategy and Plan Summary, the right third shows settings for formatting and exporting.

Figure 6: An example PDF page from the exported category strategy and plan for sharing with stakeholders, from SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over displaying one PDF page with eight cards, the top row of four cards showing charts for Spend, Top Suppliers, Top Regions, Top Subcategories, the bottom row showing lists for the values depicted in the charts.

AI-Assisted Summary for Strategy and Plan

As a category manager, you can use generative AI capabilities for generating a summary in the approval document. AI-enhanced summaries provide a quick overview, highlighting key points without the need to manually review details across all sections of the approval documents. You can refine these summaries and then submit the document for approval. Figure 7 shows an example of such a summary.

Figure 7: AI-generated strategy and plan summary in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Strategy Summary section of the Develop Strategy and Plan application, showing a full width editable text field containing text in sections “Market Dynamics”, “Category Segmentation”, “Cost Structures”. On the right above the section an AI button “Generate” is shown.

Additional enhancements

We have made some additional smaller enhancements to UI details, which improve the user’s experience. They are documented here:

  • SAP Ariba Category Management User Interface Enhancements.

Integration of the SAP User Research Panel

Getting feedback from the actual users of an application is key in order to continuously improve the user experience, and we are intensifying our efforts to reach the real users of our products, rather than the IT departmens who buy them. The SAP User Research Panel gives users the opportunity to sign-up to give feedback to SAP directly. We launched it nearly two years ago, see for example Your voice matters! Join the SAP User Research Panel. Since then many users across all areas have signed up.

We would like to encourage users of SAP Ariba to sign up too, and to make this easier, we have introduced a direct link to it from the user feedback survey. Users of SAP Ariba Category Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Risk occasionally receive a popup with a short survey asking for feedback on the product. Now, at the end of this survey, they are offered a link to sign up to the user resarch panel.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Category Management.
  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Further Information

For an overview of the key innovations with the 2508 release of SAP Ariba, have a look at this blog post:

  • SAP Ariba 2508 Release Key Innovations Preview.

 

SAP Fieldglass

Joule is now available for SAP Fieldglass, the Statement of Work (SOW) dashboard has been enhanced to allow role-specific customized views, and you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

Joule for SAP Fieldglass

Our AI copilot Joule helps users for these specific activities:

  • Selecting job posting templates
  • Selecting statement of work templates
  • Completing work items
  • Viewing quarterly trends
  • Running reports
  • Closing workers
  • Searching help content

As an example of how Joule makes work easier for users, consider finding the right template for a job posting: rather than scanning through available templates, you can just give Joule the position or project, a description, and a few other details, and Joule will provide recommendations for which template to use. Once you have chosen a template, Joule can auto-populate some of the fields, speeding the process up for you.

You can also use Joule for analytical queries: as Joule to show you quarterly trends, and Joule will show you them in the form of graphs embedded within the Joule UI.

Figure 8 shows Joule when first opened in SAP Fieldglass, with hints as clickable buttons for what you can ask for.

Figure 8: Joule in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jennifer, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Create Job Posting”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

Look at the documentation for more information:

  • Joule in SAP Fieldglass

SOW Dashboard with Customizable Views

Effective Statement of Work (SOW) management requires real-time access to critical details like spend activity, service delivery progress, and pending action items. This helps track overall SOW progress, maintain budget control, and enable informed decision-making.  Last year, we introduced the SOW Dashboard, providing a comprehensive real-time view of critical SOW data (see my last year’s blog post).

Users in different business roles need to interact with the SOW, and each role has a unique set of details relevant to them for overseeing the health of the SOW. Now, the SOW dashboard supports customized views based on user roles, which streamlines the information displayed, so that users see only what is most relevant to them. Hence, they get a more focused and efficient experience tailored to their unique needs

Figure 9 shows an example of the SOW Dashboard set up for a user focused on project status and task management. Figure 10 shows an example for a user focused on financials and spend task management.

Figure 9: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on project status and task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW Activity Items”, “SOW Line Items”, “SOW Worker Activity Items” and “Upcoming SOW Worker End Dates”. The first three are represented as lists, with color-coded summaries of items that are critical and that have warnings, the fourth shows a 2D visualization with no. of SOW workers on the y-axis and time remaining (days) on the x-axis.

Figure 10: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on financials and spend task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW with Largest Budgets”, “Deviations in Actual Spend”, “SOW Spend & Duration Alterts”, and “SOW Revisions”. The first two are represented as charts, the other two as lists.

SOW AI-Assisted Document Extraction

No matter how good the software, having to manually copy data from a document into a system to create a Statement of Work (SOW) does not rank as a great experience for most people! Now, we have significantly improved the user experience by leveraging generative AI to automate a lot of this work.

SAP Fieldglass has integrated SAP Document AI, so that users can automate the extraction and transformation of statement of work content from uploaded documents. This combined AI approach parses the source files, identifies relevant content, and generates a structured, accurate draft statement of work, reducing manual effort while improving data consistency and completeness. Figure 10 shows how users now have the new AI-enabled workflow option for creating a statement of work.

Figure 11: New AI-enabled option for creating a statement of work in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over “Create Statement of Work” containing two clickable cards: on the left “Standard Workflow” and description “Manually enter and select the details for this Statement of Work”, on the right with an AI icon “Upload Document Workflow” and description “Select a file for AI to read and populate Statement of Work details.”

Once the document has been processed, you can open the drafted statement of work to view the outcome: the AI icon appears next to sections of the document to indicate fields with content extracted using AI.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Documentation: SOW DOX (Document Extraction).

Further Information

Have a look at all the latest updates, month by month, in the

  • What’s New Viewer for SAP Fieldglass.

 

Continued soon…

I hope you enjoyed this fifth part, covering SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass.

I will post part six next week, covering latest UX innovations for selling and travel with SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur.

Part 1 of the series lists all the parts, and links to those parts that have already been published:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update – Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

For general information on design at SAP and SAP Fiori, check out:

  • www.sap.com/design.
  • www.sap.com/fiori    
  • SAP Community: SAP Fiori topic page.

entry.title: Re: Inventory Turnover Analysis" Incorrect It does not co...
entry.content:
Explore apps under the Inventory and Warehouse Management scope item (BGG), which offer broader visibility. Stock – Single Material and Stock – Multiple Materials (App IDs: F1594, F1595). These apps allow you to view special stock types, including stock provided to vendor. You can filter by stock type, movement type, and storage location.
If you need a consolidated view that includes 543/633 movements, create a Custom CDS View using I_MaterialDocumentItem or I_InventoryTransaction. Filter by movement types and join with material master and plant data. Use SAP Analytics Cloud or Fiori List Report to visualize turnover including subcontracting flows.

entry.title: Managed RAP Application for Billing Document Header and Item Tables
entry.content:
Project Overview:

Managed RAP for custom Parent Child related tables with Odata2 UI

 

Introduction:

The goal is to design a lightweight Billing Document Header and Items maintenance UI application with Create and Delete capabilities, using Managed RAP on SAP BTP ABAP Environment using Eclipse ADT. 

The application uses custom transparent tables for storing billing document header and items data and implements standard RAP layers — Database Table, Interface View, Projection View, Metadata Annotations, Behavior Definitions, Behavior Pool, Service Definition, and Service Binding.

Since this is a RAP without draft facility, the service we generate would be based on OData UI 2.0 version.

 

Objectives:

Creating a Managed RAP based UI using BTP with Create & Delete actions on custom Billing Document header and Items tables that have Parent Child relationship.

 

Tasks Outline

  1. Create required Database Table(s) – Header and Item Tables
  2. Create CDS views for the Database Table – Billing Header
    • Interface View and
    • Consumption (Projection) View
  3. Create CDS views for the Database Table – Billing Items
    • Interface View and
    • Consumption (Projection) View
  4. Create Metadata View one each for Header and Items Consumption Views
  5. Create Behavior Definition
    • for Interface View for Header and Define Items def. within
    • Create Behavior Pool implementation Class using Quick Fix option
    • Create Behavior Definition for Consumption View for Header and Define Items def. within
  6. Create Service Definition for Consumption Views of Header and Item tables
  7. Service Binding OData UI 2.0 for the Service Definition
  8. Test the application in preview/Fiori app → validate header list, object page, and item section data

 

Objects List

 

Step by Step outline:

Step 1: Create Database Tables (Eclipse - Data Dictionary-Database Table)

Step 1a: Create Billing Header Database Table (Eclipse - Data Dictionary-Database Table)

@EndUserText.label : 'Database table for BILLING header'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zdb_ar5_bill {

  key client      : abap.clnt not null;
  key bill_id     : abap.numc(10) not null;
  bill_type       : abap.char(4);
  bill_date       : abap.dats;
  customer_id     : /dmo/customer_id;
  customer_name   : abap.char(80);
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zdb_ar5_bill.currency'
  net_amount      : abap.curr(15,2);
  currency        : waers;
  sales_org       : vkorg;
  last_changed_at : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
  createdby       : syuname;
  changedby       : syuname;

}

 

Check the created Database Table structure (Right click – Open With - Data Preview)

Step1b: Create Billing Items Database Table (Eclipse - Data Dictionary-Database Table)

@EndUserText.label : 'Database table for BILLING ITEMS'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zdb_ar5_item {

  key client      : abap.clnt not null;
  key bill_id     : abap.char(10) not null;
  key item_no     : abap.numc(6) not null;
  material_id     : matnr;
  description     : abap.char(40);
  @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure : 'zsac_bill_item.uom'
  quantity        : abap.quan(13,3);
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zsac_bill_item.currency'
  item_amount     : abap.curr(15,2);
  currency        : waers;
  uom             : meins;
  last_changed_at : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
  createdby       : syuname;
  changedby       : syuname;

}

 

Check the created Database Table structure (Right click – Open With - Data Preview)

Step 2: Create Interface Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

Step 2a: Header Table – create interface root view

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface View for Billing Header'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZAR5_IR_BILL
  as select from zdb_ar5_bill       as bill
  composition [0..*] of ZAR5_I_ITEM as _item
{
  key bill_id         as BillId,
      bill_type       as BillType,
      bill_date       as BillDate,
      customer_id     as CustomerId,
      customer_name   as CustomerName,
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'Currency'
      net_amount      as NetAmount,
      currency        as Currency,
      sales_org       as SalesOrg,
      last_changed_at as LastChangedAt,
      createdby       as Createdby,
      changedby       as Changedby,

      // Associations //
      _item
}

 

Step 2b: Items Table – create interface view          

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface View for Billing item'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZAR5_I_ITEM
  as select     from        zdb_ar5_item as item
  association   to parent   ZAR5_IR_BILL as _bill 
    on          $projection.BillId       = _bill.BillId
{
  key bill_id         as BillId,
  key item_no         as ItemNo,
      material_id     as MaterialId,
      description     as Description,
      @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'Uom'
      quantity        as Quantity,
      @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'Currency'
      item_amount     as ItemAmount,
      currency        as Currency,
      uom             as Uom,
      last_changed_at as LastChangedAt,
      createdby       as Createdby,
      changedby       as Changedby,

      // Associations //
      _bill // Make association public
}

 

Step 3: Create Consumption/Projection Root view CDS for the database table created (right click database table - Data Definitions - Root View template)

Step 3a: Header Table – Projection root view creation

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Projection View for Billing Header'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true //manually added
define root view entity ZAR5_C_BILL
  provider contract transactional_query 
  as projection on ZAR5_IR_BILL
{
    key BillId,
    BillType,
    BillDate,
    CustomerId,
    CustomerName,
    @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'
    NetAmount,
    Currency,
    SalesOrg,
    LastChangedAt,
    Createdby,
    Changedby,
    
    /* Associations */
    _item :  redirected to composition child ZAR5_C_ITEM
   
}

 

Step 3b: Item Table – Projection view creation

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Projection View for Billing item'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true //manually added
define view entity ZAR5_C_ITEM
    as projection on ZAR5_I_ITEM
{
    key BillId,
    key ItemNo,
    MaterialId,
    Description,
    @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'Uom'
    Quantity,
    @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'
    ItemAmount,
    Currency,
    Uom,
    LastChangedAt,
    Createdby,
    Changedby,
    
    /* Associations */
    _bill : redirected to parent ZAR5_C_BILL  
   
}

 

Step 4: Create Metadata that helps with designing aspects of the UI (Right click on the Projection View you created and select new "Metadata Definition")

Step 4a: Create Metadata for Header Table

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI: {
  headerInfo: {
    typeName:        'Billing Document Header',
    typeNamePlural:  'Billing Documents',
    title: {
      type:  #STANDARD,
      label: 'Billing Document',
      value: 'BillId'
    }
  }
}

annotate entity ZAR5_C_BILL with
{
  @ui.facet: [
    {
      id:       'BillingDocHead',
      purpose:  #STANDARD,
      type:     #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE,
      label:    'Header',
      position: 10
    },
    {
      id:            'BillingDocItem',
      purpose:       #STANDARD,
      type:          #LINEITEM_REFERENCE,
      label:         'Items',
      position:      20,
      targetElement: '_item'
    }
  ]

  // --- START OF FINAL CORRECTION ---

  // All columns and buttons for the list report table go inside this SINGLE lineItem array.
  @ui.lineItem: [
    // Object 1: The column for the BillId field
    {
      position: 10,
      importance: #HIGH
    },
    // Object 2: The button for the setFullName action
    {
      type:       #FOR_ACTION,
      dataAction: 'setFullName',
      label:      'Set Customer Name',
      position: 15  // Position for the button in the toolbar
    },
     // Object 3: The button for the COPY action
    {
      type:       #FOR_ACTION,
      dataAction: 'copyBillDoc',
      label:      'Copy to Create',
      position: 16  // Position for the button in the toolbar
    }
  ]
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 10 } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 10 } ]
  @EndUserText.label: 'Billing Document'
  BillId;

  // --- END OF FINAL CORRECTION ---


  @EndUserText.label: 'Billing Document Type'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 20 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 20 } ],
    selectionField: [ { position: 20 } ]
  }
  BillType;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Billing Date'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 30 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 30 } ]
  }
  BillDate;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Customer'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 40 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 40 } ]
  }
  CustomerId;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Customer Name'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 45 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 45 } ]
  }
  CustomerName;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Net Amount'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 50 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 50 } ]
  }
  NetAmount;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Currency'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 60 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 60 } ]
  }
  Currency;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Sales Organization'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 70 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 70 } ]
  }
  SalesOrg;
}

 

Step 4b: Create Metadata for Item Table

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity ZAR5_C_ITEM with
{
  @ui.facet: [ {
  id:       'BillingDocItem',
  purpose:  #STANDARD,
  type:     #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE,
  label:    'Item',
  position: 10
  }]
  @ui: {
    identification: [ { position: 10 } ],
    selectionField: [ { position: 10 } ]
  }
  BillId;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Item Number'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 20 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 20 } ],
    selectionField: [ { position: 20 } ]
  }
  ItemNo;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Material'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 30 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 30 } ]
  }
  MaterialId;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Description'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 40 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 40 } ]
  }
  Description;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Quantity'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 50 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 50 } ]
  }
  Quantity;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Unit of Measure'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 60 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 60 } ]
  }
  Uom;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Amount'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 70 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 70 } ]
  }
  ItemAmount;
  @EndUserText.label: 'Currency'
  @ui: {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 80 } ],
    identification: [ { position: 80 } ]
  }
  Currency;
}

Step5: Create Behaviour Definition - one for Interface view and one for Consumption view.

Step 5a: Create Behaviour Definition for Header interface view ((Right click the Interface CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

managed implementation in class zbp_ar5_ir_bill unique;
strict ( 2 );

//Headewr table interface view definition
define behavior for ZAR5_IR_BILL alias bill
persistent table zdb_ar5_bill
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
etag master LastChangedAt
{
  create ( authorization : global );
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly ) BillId;
  association _item { create; }

    mapping for zdb_ar5_bill
    {
        BillId        = bill_id;
        BillDate      = bill_date;
        BillType      = bill_type;
        CustomerId    = customer_id;
        CustomerName  = customer_name;
        NetAmount     = net_amount;
        Currency      = currency;
        SalesOrg      = sales_org;
        LastChangedAt = last_changed_at;
        createdby     = createdby;
        changedby     = changedby;
    }
}
//Item table interface view definition
define behavior for ZAR5_I_ITEM alias item
persistent table zdb_ar5_item
lock dependent by _bill
authorization dependent by _bill
etag master LastChangedAt
{
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly ) BillId, ItemNo;
  association _bill;

  mapping for zdb_ar5_item
    {
      BillId      = bill_id;
      ItemNo      = item_no;
      MaterialId  = material_id;
      Description = description;
      Quantity    = quantity;
      ItemAmount  = item_amount;
      Currency    = currency;
      Uom         = uom;
      LastChangedAt = last_changed_at;
      createdby   = createdby;
      changedby   = changedby;
    }
}

 

Step 5b: Create Behaviour Pool – Implementation class (from the Quick Fix facility on the first line of the definition above).Activate the generated class – no change required since we have no custom logic to be implemented.

CLASS lhc_bill DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR bill RESULT result.

    METHODS get_global_authorizations FOR GLOBAL AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR bill RESULT result.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_bill IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_global_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 

Step 5c: Create Behaviour Definition for the Projection view (Right click the Projection CDS View and choose Behaviour Definition option)

projection;
strict ( 2 );

with managed instance filter;

define behavior for ZAR5_C_BILL alias bill
use etag
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;

  use association _item { create; }
}

define behavior for ZAR5_C_ITEM alias item
{
  use update;
  use delete;

  use association _bill;
}

Step 6: Create Service definition (Right click CDS Projection Header View and click "New Service Definition"). Expose the Consumption Views of Header and Item.

@EndUserText.label: 'Service Def. for Proj. View of Header'
define service ZSD_AR5_BILL {
  expose ZAR5_C_BILL as BillingParentChildApp;
  expose ZAR5_C_ITEM as BillingItems;
}

Step 7: Create Service Binding (Right click on the new Service definition you created and choose "New Service Binding" and Choose OData V4 version for the UI)

Select the Service Definition displayed on the versions section of the page and hit "Publish" button. Once published, a Service URL will be created and the binding will be displayed.

 

Step 8: Test the Application: Select the Entity and hit Preview button(see screenshot above) , a new Window will be opened with the RAP UI App you created.

 

Click “Go” Button, so that the values are pulled from the Database table to be shown on the screen.

You can see the database records displayed on the screen. The Create and Delete buttons are available for creating new records and deleting existing records. When user clicks on a particular record the object page opens up with Items table details.

The user can navigate to each items record displayed to see additional information.

If you are a beginner I recommend my blog :

Simple RAP based Managed UI development with Create & Delete actions on custom BillDoc header table 

Conclusion

By leveraging Managed RAP, you do not need to write custom CRUD logic for database tables in parent-child relation— the framework auto-generates this functionality, allowing you to focus purely on data modelling, UI annotations, and service exposure.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud ABAP Environment
